title: Don’t Fear The Simulators
summary:
Key ideas:
- The New York Times recently published an article about the possibility of living in a simulation.
- The article proposes testing the hypothesis but also argues against it, suggesting that discovering that we are in a simulation may cause the simulators to destroy the universe.
- The author argues that the simulators must have a monitoring system to simulate billions of sentient beings and would be able to prevent us from discovering that we are in a simulation.
- The author also suggests that this may not be the simulators' only project and that they would care about simulation-related philosophy.

Key learnings:
- The simulators must have a monitoring system to simulate billions of sentient beings.
- The simulators would be able to prevent us from discovering that we are in a simulation.
- The simulators may have other projects and care about simulation-related philosophy.

Key questions:
- Do the simulators destroy all simulations that develop radio-wave technology and start checking the cosmic background radiation?
- Do the simulators have fail-safes to prevent simulations from figuring out they are in a simulation?
- Should we worry about becoming too computationally intensive and getting our simulation terminated?
